book_name: An Elegant Puzzle - Systems of Engineering Management - by Will Larson.pdf
summary: In organizational management, having a varied group of individuals lead critical projects is vital for fostering inclusivity and enhancing throughput. This chapter outlines a structured approach to selecting project leads, emphasizing the importance of clear communication and accessibility. The process includes defining project goals, allowing private applications, and offering feedback to non-selected applicants. By nurturing a wider pool of project leaders, organizations can promote growth and learning across the team. Ultimately, this approach enhances both organizational health and individual professional development.

slides.section_body: Consistently relied upon project leaders can limit organizational growth and throughput. It is essential to have a broad cohort of leaders for critical projects to foster a healthier organizational culture. By diversifying project leadership, everyone gets a chance to learn and contribute.
slides.quote: A wide cohort of leaders signifies good organizational health.

slides.section_body: Understanding the difference between critical projects and abundant projects is crucial. Critical projects are limited in number and highly sought after, whereas abundant projects are plentiful and accessible. This distinction helps set clear expectations for team members.
slides.quote: Critical projects are scarce; abundant projects are plentiful.

slides.section_body: Implementing a structured process for selecting project leads enhances transparency and accessibility. Start by clearly defining the project's scope and establishing criteria for selection. This ensures everyone knows the goals and expectations ahead.
slides.quote: A structured selection process fosters inclusivity.

slides.section_body: Ensure that all team members are made aware of the opportunity to lead projects. Use a variety of communication methods to announce the project and allow private applications to encourage participation from all levels.
slides.quote: Public notification combined with private application promotes inclusivity.

slides.section_body: Mentor and nudge individuals who may be hesitant to apply for leadership roles. By actively encouraging participation, organizations can foster new talent and diversify their leadership pool, enriching the project experience.
slides.quote: Encouraging potential candidates opens new avenues for growth.

slides.section_body: Carefully evaluate all applicants against the established criteria. Providing feedback is key—letting those not selected know why they weren’t chosen can help them grow and prepare for future opportunities.
slides.quote: Feedback is a crucial part of the selection process.

slides.section_body: Once a project lead is selected, pair them with a sponsor who can guide them through the project. This mentorship not only supports the leader but also enriches the sponsor's own professional development.
slides.quote: Sponsorship creates a strong support system for leaders.

slides.section_body: Following the selection, announce the project leader and their sponsor to the team. This creates a sense of accountability and ensures everyone is on the same page regarding the project's goals and leadership.
slides.quote: Clear communication at kickoff sets the stage for success.

slides.section_body: Keeping a public record of project leaders and sponsors provides transparency and helps capture who takes on important projects. This encourages future applications and a sense of involvement from all team members.
slides.quote: Documentation fosters a culture of accountability and growth.

slides.section_body: Although the structured approach may initially feel clunky, it is essential for building a diverse leadership cohort. Over time, this method strengthens organizational health and promotes a culture of learning and inclusion.
slides.quote: Long-term success lies in nurturing diverse opportunities.
